instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB short to ground
threads.message:
For some reason I can't post pictures, format not working or something.

Anyway, liquid damage everywhere but SD and a USB port not working.

​​​​​​​I'm getting 3.3v (a bit less but nothing like a short) at EN and output. <DIODE>D9410</DIODE> is getting 3.3v, so what the hell is dragging this thing down to ground?

<CHIP>U9410</CHIP> and the resistors and caps around it were replaced. Pin, 7, 6, 5 are still shorted and getting nothing at <CAPACITOR>C9412</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R9410</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9411</RESISTOR> but about 2mA at <CAPACITOR>C9410</CAPACITOR> and very slowly climbs up a little.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB short to ground
threads.message: <CHIP>U9310</CHIP> is getting 0.5v as well. Not sure if I'm just using crappy parts from the damaged boards I'm using as donors.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB short to ground
threads.message:
<CHIP>U9410</CHIP> gets input power from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, via <RESISTOR>R0960</RESISTOR>.
<CHIP>U9310</CHIP>, <CHIP>U9410</CHIP> are used for dispay port and T29 connector, not for USB.

Which USB por is shorted?

As you have corroded board, check L4600/10 and L4605/15 first.
Also check around <DIODE>D4600</DIODE>/10 and <CHIP>U4650</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB short to ground
threads.message: Thanks for the reply. I spent way too much time on this board and got things mixed up. Had to replace about 30 components. I meant display port and actually completely forgot about checking USB circuitry cause of this annoying short that seems to be in the board. I'll have to see if the USB port is grounded to the same spot. It's J4600. I've fixed this problem before but this board is pretty bad.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB short to ground
threads.message:
The board doesn't need display port and T29 circuitry to start.
If you have a short there, just isolate it; remove <TRANSISTOR>Q3880</TRANSISTOR>, I think <RESISTOR>R0960</RESISTOR> is not stuffed.
If client doesn't need these connections, rip off <CHIP>U3810</CHIP>/15/16 too. You can use them as spare parts for other repairs.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B USB short to ground
threads.message: Nope. Removed those and I double checked the USB circuitry and they weren't getting power from <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> and  <CHIP>U2650</CHIP> (USB hubs). I reflowed the SMC very gently and now the board shuts down when I touch ground with the ground probe. I give up for now, spent too much time on this. Appreciate the help.
